results.title: The Crisis = La Crise
results.creator_credit: Coline Serreau, Alain Sarde, Les Films Alain Sarde and TFI Films
results.brief_description: A heartfelt French comedy whose warmth and humour is matched equally by its biting and poignant commentary on social, political and racial issues in France in the early 1990s. Victor (Vincent Lindon), a smart and successful lawyer, is deserted by his wife and fired on the same day. He turns to his colleagues, his friends, his family, but all have troubled and complex lives and have no time to deal with his as well. Enter Michou (Patrick Timsit), a wandering barfly who attaches himself to Victor, both comedic and wise in the effect he has on the lives he touches and most of all on Victor and on the journey through which his sudden crisis takes him. Through their interaction with each other and those around them, brief or lasting, and the humorous antics that befall the unlikely pair, Serreau constructs a striking fairy tale with a subtle political, social and racial critique that confronts the dual existence of humanity and hypocrisy in its many forms in contemporary society. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: The Dead next door
results.creator_credit: J.R. Bookwalter, Amsco Studios and Suburban Tempe
results.brief_description: J.R. Bookwalter’s The Dead Next Door is more than a passing homage to director George A. Romero’s ‘Living Dead’ trilogy. Shot on super-8 and partly financed by director Sam Raimi, this super low budget effort might be creaky at times but enthusiastically serves up the gore to considerable effect. The thin plot concerns a crack team of soldiers know as The Zombie squad who are called in to contain a virus that is bringing the dead back to life. Of course the zombies aren’t content with just being re-animated, as they chew their way through the human race leaving a messy trail behind them. Complicating the commandos squads mission further is an insane religious cult whose sole aim is to keep the zombies fed and alive in preparation for the final day of reckoning when the dead will finally replace the living. Cast includes Peter Ferry, Bogdan Pecic, Jolie Jackunas, Robert Kokai.

results.title: The Island
results.creator_credit: Michael Ritchie, David Brown, Richard Zanuck and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on Peter Benchley’s novel and adapted for the screen by him, “The Island” unfortunately does not match up to Benchley’s box office hit “Jaws”. The story is set in the Caribbean, in the Bermuda Triangle, an area where pleasure crafts and fishing boats have a habit of mysteriously disappearing, along with their passengers and crew. Blair Maynard (Michael Caine) is a journalist who sets out, along with his son, Justin (Jeffrey Frank), to try and discover the reason for the disappearances. It is during a fishing trip in the accursed area that Maynard and his son are captured by pirates, who are supposedly descendants from seventeenth century pirates and who still live by the same code, that is, robbing and murdering all those who sail close to their island shores. Maynard is kept alive to serve the needs of “regenerating” the blood-line of the pirates, and Nau, King of the pirates (David Warner), takes to converting Justin to their heathen ways. But escape for Maynard becomes paramount and the action and thrills begin to build as the film heads towards its tumultuous climax. Cast also includes Angela Punch McGregor, Frank Middlemass, Don Henderson, Dudley Sutton, Colin Jeavons. Music composed and conducted by Ennio Morricone.

results.title: What women want [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Nancy Meyers, Bruce Davey, Gina Matthews, Matt Williams, Susan Cartonis, Centropolis Effects, ICON, Paramount Pictures and Wind Dancer Productions
results.brief_description: Nick Marshall (Mel Gibson) is a real ladies man. Raised by his mother, a Las Vegas showgirl, he has a somewhat distorted perception of what women really want, and an enormous ego. When he is passed over for an executive position in the advertising agency for a woman his chauvinistic attitude worsens. A freak accident while trying to brainstorm ideas for a new advertising campaign, leaves Nick with the ability to hear what women think. Amazed by his new talent Nick seeks the help of a therapist (Bette Midler) who suggests he think of it as a gift and not a curse, and to use this to his advantage. Nick sets his sights on Darcy McGuire (Helen Hunt), the new creative director in the agency. At first his plan works, and he undermines Darcy at every opportunity, until he realises Darcy has feelings for him, and that he feels the same way about her. Cast also includes Marisa Tomei, Mark Feurstein, Lauren Holly, Valerie Perrine, Delta Bourke and Alan Alda.

results.title: Newsfront [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, David Elfick, Richard Brennan and Palm Beach Pictures
results.brief_description: This is the dramatic story of the newsreel cameramen who lived and worked in Australia during the golden era of the newsreel from 1948 to 1956. Len Maguire is a top cameraman whose devotion to his work and loyalty to his company creates conflict with both his colleagues and the people he loves. Amy is a production assistant working in a predominantly male environment and Len’s brother, Frank, heads the Australian branch of an American newsreel company in competition with Len’s company.

results.title: Harry and Walter go to New York
results.creator_credit: Mark Rydell, Don Devlin, Harry Gittes, Tony Bill, Columbia and Safecracker Productions
results.brief_description: This comedy caper film set in the 1890’s (the period meticulously re-created by art director Harry Horner) features James Caan and Elliot Gould as a vaudeville song and dance team who, after being thrown into jail on a petty theft charge make the acquaintance of a big time crook (Michael Caine). Together they devise a plot to execute a major bank robbery - with disastrous results. Cast also includes Diane Keaton.

results.title: Funeral in Berlin
results.creator_credit: Guy Hamilton, Charles Kasher, Paramount Pictures and Ken Adam
results.brief_description: In this 60’s espionage classic (a follow up to “The Ipcress File”), Michael Caine reprises his role as British secret agent, Harry Palmer, who reluctantly takes on a job in Berlin where his task is to organise the defection of a wily Russian military commander from East Berlin. Using his local underworld contacts, he arranges for the border crossing to take place in a coffin, as part of a mock funeral. Pursued by a glamorous Israeli agent and hindered by double dealing within his own organisation, Harry Palmer brings his own Cockney cunning to the fore to survive when his plans are thwarted and the wrong body arrives in the coffin. Based on a novel by Len Deighton.

results.title: Blood and wine
results.creator_credit: Bob Rafelson, Jeremy Thomas and Blood and wine Productions
results.brief_description: Alex Gates (Jack Nicholson) is down on his luck: struggling to keep afloat his wine business, unhappily married to the snappy Suzanne (Judy Davis), who gave him the money to first start the business, and step-father to the hostile Jason (Stephen Dorff), Gates seeks an escape. His secret lover, the Latino Gabriella (Jennifer Lopez), is a nanny at a rich Florida family home, which provides the necessary inside connection for Gates and his ruthless partner-in-crime, Victor Spansky, played to hammy effect by Michael Caine, to steal a set of expensive diamonds. Though the robbery goes according to plan, all hopes are quickly dashed when Gates gets into a domestic brawl just before leaving to cash in the jewels and his wife and step-son take off with the goods. What follows is a series of tragic events and complications as Spansky and Gates attempt to retrieve the jewels, and Gabriella becomes involved with Jason. Ultimately, the deceitful are punished and the good set free. “Blood and Wine” has all the elements of film noir - lust, deceit, revenge, greed, crime, and, most importantly, the desire to escape conventional constraints. Bob Rafelson, who has carved out a reputation as a director of contemporary film noir, remaking such classics as “The Postman Always Rings Twice” (1981), and character-studies of drifting and alienation in middle-class America, continues in “Blood and Wine” his close collaboration with Jack Nicholson, making this their eighth film and the final instalment in a trilogy of films of ‘dysfunctional families’, including “Five Easy Pieces” (1970) and “The King of Marvin Gardens” (1972). Interweaving familial ties with criminal pursuit, “Blood and Wine” makes Oedipal themes - such as the struggle between father and son - typical of film noir more overt. Ultimately, stereotyped characters (sexy Latino, frustrated housewife, ruthless, exotic criminal) and an inability to reach the dramatic heights or transgressive thrills of classic noir makes “Blood and Wine” a rather conventional reworking of the genre.

results.title: The Last valley
results.creator_credit: James Clavell, ABC Pictures (US) and Season Productions
results.brief_description: Set in 17th century Austria during the Thirty Years’ War, “The Last valley” adapted from J.B. Pick’s novel was written, directed and produced by noted novelist and occasional film director, James Clavell (Shogun, The Great escape). This is a story of war and peace, of soldiers and villagers and a beautiful hidden valley which lies protected from the ravages of war going on around it. Vogel (Omar Sharif), once a school teacher but now on the run, has the fortune to stumble across the peaceful village where he is given lodgings in return for protection. The peace and calm soon erupts into conflict and violence however, when an exhausted army of soldiers led by “The Captain” (Michael Caine) also discover the hidden valley. A truce with the village community and “The Captain” is arranged through the mediation of Vogel, pledging to protect the people of the valley from invasion in return for food and shelter over the cold winter months. Filmed in Todd A-O and on location in Trins in Tirol, Austria. Cast also includes Florinda Bolkan, Nigel Davenport, Per Oscarsson.

Vogel (Omar Sharif), once a school teacher but now on the run, has the fortune to stumble across the peaceful village where he is given lodgings in return for protection. The peace and calm soon erupts into conflict and violence however, when an exhausted army of soldiers led by “The Captain” (Michael Caine) also discover the hidden valley. A truce with the village community and “The Captain” is arranged through the mediation of Vogel, pledging to protect the people of the valley from invasion in return for food and shelter over the cold winter months. Filmed in Todd A-O and on location in Trins in Tirol, Austria. Cast also includes Florinda Bolkan, Nigel Davenport, Per Oscarsson.
